docs.abstract: Leslie Berger article on increasing use of psychotherapy by college students that is forcing campus mental health services to re-evaluate their mission and expand; concerns remain over waiting times for appintments and frequent referrals off campus, especially at schools far from medical centers; photos (special section, Education Life) (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: YOU see him walking north on Broadway, arms swinging, legs moving at such a brisk clip that you almost miss him, and suddenly you're sucked into the force field of a very busy, self-confident Co-lumbia University sophomore. The woman at the newsstand recognizes him and knows his brand of cigarettes, Dunhill Internationals. The freshman he bumps into at the corner, an eager fraternity pledge, solicits his advice on proper dress for a party later on. ''I want you to look sharp, man,'' he tells the freshman, punching his arm. The pretty java jerk at Starbucks knows his preferred form of caffeine. ''Another quad, huh?'' she asks, laughing about the quadruple es-presso he downs three times a day.

headline.main: Better Memory: It Doesn't Come in a Pill

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on memory, memory decline and memory disorders; guidelines for staying sharp (M)2
docs.lead_paragraph: When I complained to my son Erik about things I can no longer remember, he replied: ''What do you expect? With all you've stuffed into your head all these years, something is bound to fall out.'' Along with the many notes on my fridge reminding me of things I have to do is a New Yorker cartoon depicting an elephant covered with Post-its, who tells his unadorned companion, ''As I get older, I find I rely more and more on these sticky notes to remind me.''
